content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Coded in just a few minutes with a very clear statement. Nice!

Good overall, but the description seems a bit disorganized. Here is what I suggest changing it to:

"A pirate stacks his cannonballs in a pyramid, starting with a square base. Each tier above is a smaller square, with each side containing one less cannonball than the tier below. This continues until a single cannonball sits at the top. For example, a valid two-tiered pyramid has a base of four cannonballs in a 2Ã—2 square, with one resting on top."

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great bit of 3d thinking, good job.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Liked it!

Hello,
I've corrected everything you indicated. Is it correct now?

Sincerely,
Pandaroux007

Goal
* Please add:
In general, the number of cannonballs in the [[i]]-th level of the pyramid is [[i]] squared.

* Please change "the stack" to "the pyramid".

* Please change "store" to "stack".

* Please format "cannonball in the sea!" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Output
* Please change "Just an integer" to "Line 1".

* Please add "or {{cannonball in the sea!}}".

Cases
* Each test should be similar to its corresponding validator, but not the same. Please revise the validators accordingly, e.g.

   â€¢ [[N]] is a small integer for Test 1 and Validator 1.

   â€¢ [[N]] is a 3-digit integer for Test 2 and Validator 2.

   â€¢ [[N]] is a 5-digit integer for Test 3 and Validator 3.

   â€¢ [[N]] does not make a perfect pyramid for Test 4 and Validator 4.

Thanks.

Hello and thank you for your comment!
I have normally corrected everything except the "Cases" part because I don't understand it unfortunately, I am French but even the English version I don't understand... I don't know how to make different results for Tests and Validators because there is only one number for a value? My apologies!

Sincerely,
Pandaroux007

No worries! I'll explain to you.

The purpose of having validators is to prevent players from seeing them and hardcoding their solution. Except for edge cases, each test should be different from validators. But they should be similar enough so that what the player can see during coding is similar to what they are assessed after code submission.

Test = visible case for coding
Validator = hidden case for calculating final score

For example, you may set the input of Test 2 as 819 and that of Validator 2 as 506.
Okay thanks, now I see what these elements are for - I'll fix the contribution right away!

Thanks! The cases look ok now.

(P.S. I won't know you've finished if you start a separate thread of comment ðŸ˜‰)
(Edited:) IMO stating squared (numbers) gives a lot away. Each is supported by 4, examples for 2 and (maybe) 3 tiers suffice.

Pyramids can have a square or triangular base (I'm not sure whether there are other possibilities). Therefore, the problem statement should at least specify the type of pyramid (e.g., each tier is a square with a side length one unit larger than the tier above), even if it doesnâ€™t include a detailed example of a two-tier pyramid.
For orderly stacking, yes: Only triangles, squares, and hexagons tile the plane in a regular way, but hexagons wouldn't work.

OK. So, based on your earlier comment,

These two sentences should be deleted:
â€¢ for a two-tiered pyramid, there are five cannonballs: four at the bottom, arranged in a square, and one at the top.

â€¢ (In general, the number of cannonballs in the i-th level of the pyramid is i squared.)

And replaced with:
â€¢ each tier is a square with a side length one unit larger than the tier above.

â€¢ For example, a 2-tiered pyramid consists of 5 cannonballs, and a 3-tiered pyramid consists of 14 cannonballs.

Does that sound good to you?

Yes, if the author feels so inclined, my preference might be a mixture, explaining the picture rather than the formula:

for a two-tiered pyramid, there are five cannonballs: four at the bottom, arranged in a square, and one at the top. Each tier is a square with a side length one unit larger than the tier above.
Sounds good to me.

Hello and thank you for your comment!
I added your suggestion, please tell me if it's correct!
"for a two-tiered pyramid, there are five cannonballs: four at the bottom, arranged in a square, and one at the top. Each tier is a square with a side length one unit larger than the tier above."

Sincerely,
Pandaroux007
Thank you. The revision is correct, and please remove the last sentence ("In generalâ€¦") too.
Oops, a small oversight indeed - it's been corrected!
No worries! Thanks ðŸ˜‰
